regimen.name: Bevacizumab/Irinotecan
regimen.schedule:
Bevacizumab 15 mg/kg IV
Repeat Every 21 Days
Irinotecan 350 mg/m2 with enzyme-inducing antiepileptic drugs, days 1, 8, 22, 29
OR
Irinotecan 125 mg/m2 with non-enzyme-including antiepileptic drugs, IV, days 1, 8, 22, 29
Repeat every 6 weeks
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment
  • Irinotecan:
    If bilirubin 1-2 mg/dL, may need to reduce the dose
    If bilurubin > 2 mg/dL, may not use  
Renal Impairment
  • Irinotecan:
    No dose reduction

references.referenceValue: Vredenburgh JJ, Desjardins A, Herndon JE, et al. Bevacizumab plus irinotecan in recurrent glioblastoma multiforme.

regimen.name: PCV
regimen.schedule:
Procarbazine 60 mg/m2/d PO, days 8-21
Lomustine 110 mg/m2 PO, day 1
Vincristine 1.4 mg/m2 IV, days 8, 29
Repeat every 6 weeks upto 7 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment
  • Lomustine:
    No dose reduction
  • Vincristine:
    If bilirubin 1.5-3 mg/dL or SGOT 60-180 mg/dL, reduce dose by 50%
    If bilirubin > 3 mg/dL or SGOT > 180 mg/dL, do not use
Renal Impairment
  • Lomustine:
    If CrCl < 60 mL/min, do not use
  • Procarbazine:
    If CrCl < 30 mL/min, do not use
  • Vincristine:
    No dose reduction

references.referenceValue: Levin VA, Uhm JH, Jaeckle KA, et al. Phase III randomized study of postradiotherapy chemotherapy with alpha-difluromethylornithine- procarbazine, N-(2-chloroethyl)-N' -cyclohexyl- N-nitrosuera, vincristine (DFMO-PCV) versus PCV for glioblastoma multiforme.

regimen.name: Temozolomide+RT
regimen.schedule:
Temozolomide 75 mg/m2 daily along with radiation
FOLLOWED 28 DAYS LATER BY
Temozolomidee 150 mg/m2 daily for 5 days
Repeat every 28 days.
regimen.emetogenicPotential:
Moderate for IV
<=75 mg/m2 PO is minimal-low;
>75 mg/m2 PO is moderate-high
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment
  • Temozolomide:
    No dose reduction
Renal Impairment

references.referenceValue: Stupp R, et al.  Radiotherapy plus Concomitant and Adjuvant Temozolomide for Glioblastoma.

regimen.name: BCNU (Carmustine)

Renal Impairment

Neurosurgery.2002;51(2):343-355; discussion 355-357.

regimen.name: Carboplatin/Fluorouracil/Cetuximab
regimen.schedule:
Carboplatin AUC of 5, day 1
Fluorouracil 1,000 mg/m2/d CIVI, days 1-4
Repeat every 21 days for a maximum of 6 cycles
Cetuximab 400 mg/m2 IV load over 4 hours, day 1, cycle 1 THEN 250 mg/m2 IV over 1 hour, every week.
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment
  • Carboplatin:
    No dose reduction
  • Fluorouracil:
    If bilirubin < 5 mg/dL, no dose reduction
    If bilirubin > 5 mg/dL, do not use
    No dose reduction for infusional administration
Renal Impairment
  • Carboplatin:
    Dosing based on AUC
  • Fluorouracil:
    No dose reduction

references.referenceValue: Vermorken JB, Mesia R, Rivera F, et al. Platinum-based chemotherapy plus cetuximab in head and neck cancer.

regimen.name: CP
regimen.schedule:
Cisplatin 75 mg/m2, day 1 and
Paclitaxel 175 mg/m2 over 3 hours on day 1
Repeat cycle every 21 days
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment
  • Cisplatin:
    No dose reduction
  • Paclitaxel:
    For 3-hour infusion:
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.25 upper normal limit, no dose reduction (175mg/m2)
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.26-2 upper normal limit, reduce to 135 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin2.01-5 upper normal limit, reduce to 90 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 5 upper normal limit, do not use
    For 24-hour infusion:
    If transaminase < 2 upper normal limit or bilirubin < 1.5 mg/mL, no dose reduction (135 mg/m2)
    If transaminase 2-10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.5 mg/dL, reduce to 100 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.6-7.5 mg/dL, reduce to 50 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 7.5 mg/dL, do not use
Renal Impairment
  • Cisplatin:
    If CrCl 30-60 mL/min, reduce dose by 50%
    If CrCl < 30 mL/min, do not use
  • Paclitaxel:
    No dose reduction

references.referenceValue: Gibson MK, Li Y, Murphy B, et al. Randomized phase III evaluation of cisplatin plus fluorouracil versus cisplatin plus paclitaxel in advanced head and neck cancer (E1395): an intergroup trial of the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group.

regimen.name: TPF
regimen.schedule:
Docetaxelb 75mg/m2 IV over 1 hour, day1
Cisplatin 75mg/m2 IV over 1 hour, day 1
Fluorouraacil 750 mg/m2/d, days 1-5
Repeat every 21 days
OR
Docetaxelb 75 mg/m2 IV, day 1
Cisplatin 100 mg/m2 IV, day 1
Fluorouracil 1,000 mg/m2/d CIVI, days 1-4
Repeat every 21 days for 3 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment
  • Cisplatin:
    No dose reduction
  • Docetaxel:
    If bilirubin > upper normal limit, do not use
    If  SGOT and/or SGPT > 1.5 upper normal limit plus alkaline Phosphatase >2.5 upper normal limit, do not use
Renal Impairment
  • Cisplatin:
    If CrCl 30-60 mL/min, reduce dose by 50%
    If CrCl < 30 mL/min, do not use
  • Docetaxel:
    No dose reduction

references.referenceValue: Vermorken JB, Remenar E, Van Herpen C, et al. Cisplatin, fluorouracil, and docetaxel in unresectable head and neck cancer.
Posner MR, Hershock DM, Blajman CR, et al. Cisplatin and fluorouracil alone or with docetaxel in head and neck cancer.

    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.26-2 upper normal limit, reduce to 135 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin2.01-5 upper normal limit, reduce to 90 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 5 upper normal limit, do not use
    For 24-hour infusion:
    If transaminase < 2 upper normal limit or bilirubin < 1.5 mg/mL, no dose reduction (135 mg/m2)
    If transaminase 2-10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.5 mg/dL, reduce to 100 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.6-7.5 mg/dL, reduce to 50 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 7.5 mg/dL, do not use
Renal Impairment
  • Cisplatin:
    If CrCl 30-60 mL/min, reduce dose by 50%
    If CrCl < 30 mL/min, do not use

    No dose reduction

Oxaliplatin130 mg/m2 IV on day 1

regimen.schedule:

Cisplatin: 60 mg/m2 IV on day 2

regimen.name: ELF
regimen.schedule:
Leucovorin calcium 300 mg/m2/d IV over 10 minutes, FOLLOWED BY
Etoposide 120 mg/m2/d IV over 50 minutes,
THEN
Fluorouracil 500 mg/m2/d IV bolus
Give all agents on days 1-3; repeat every 22 days
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment
  • Etoposide:
    If bilirubin 1.5-3 mg/dL or SGOT 60-180 mg/dL, reduce dose by 50%
    If bilirubin > 3 mg/dL or SGOT > 180 mg/dL, do not use
  • Fluorouracil:
    If bilirubin < 5 mg/dL, no dose reduction
    If bilirubin > 5 mg/dL, do not use
    No dose reduction for infusional administration
Renal Impairment
  • Etoposide:
    If CrCl 10-50 mL/min, reduce dose by 25%
    If CrCl < 10 mL/min, reduce dose by 50%
  • Fluorouracil:
    No dose reduction

references.referenceValue: Vanhoefer U, Rougier P, Wilke H, et al. Final results of a randomized phase III trial of sequential high-dose methotrexate, fluorouracil, and doxorubicin versus etoposide, leucovorin, and fluorouracil versus infusional flurorouracil and cisplatin in advanced gastric cancer: a trial of the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Gasttrointestinal Tract Cancer Cooperative Group.

Leucovorin calcium 20 mg/m2/d, on the first 4 and last 3 days of RT,
FOLLOWED BY
Fluorouracil 425 mg/m2/d for 5 days
Leucovorin calcium 20 mg/m2/d for 5 days
repeat 28 days X 2 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:

    No dose reduction for infusional administration
Renal Impairment
  • Fluorouracil:
    No dose reduction

references.referenceValue: Macdonald JS, Smalley SR, Benedetti J, et al. Chemoradiotherapy afer surgery compared with surgery alone for adenocarcinoma of the stomach or gastroesophageal junction.

  • Cisplatin:

    If CrCl < 30 mL/min, do not use
  • Fluorouracil:
    No dose reduction

    If transaminase 2-10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.5 mg/dL, reduce to 100 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.6-7.5 mg/dL, reduce to 50 mg/m2

Renal Impairment
  • Carboplatin:

  • Paclitaxel:
    No dose reduction

regimen.name: A - T - C (dose-dense)
regimen.schedule:
Doxorubicin 60 mg/m2 IV ,every 14 days for 4 cycles, FOLLOWED BY
Paclitaxel 175 mg/m2 IV, every 14 days for 4 cycles, FOLLOWED BY
Cyclophosphamide 600 mg/m2 IV, every 14 days for 4 cycles
Filgrastim (prophylactic) given on days 3-10 of each cycleOR PEG-Filgastrim 6 mg SQ on day 2.
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment
  • Cyclophosphamide:
    If bilirubin 3-5 mg/dL or SGOT > 180 mg/dL, reduce dose by 25%
    If bilirubin >5 mg/dL, do not use
  • Doxorubicin:
    If bilirubin 1.2-3 mg/dL, reduce dose by 50%
    If bilirubin 3.1-5 mg/dL, reduce dose by 75%
    If bilirubin >5 mg/dL, do not use
  • Paclitaxel:
    For 3-hour infusion:
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.25 upper normal limit, no dose reduction (175mg/m2)
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.26-2 upper normal limit, reduce to 135 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin2.01-5 upper normal limit, reduce to 90 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 5 upper normal limit, do not use
    For 24-hour infusion:
    If transaminase < 2 upper normal limit or bilirubin < 1.5 mg/mL, no dose reduction (135 mg/m2)
    If transaminase 2-10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.5 mg/dL, reduce to 100 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.6-7.5 mg/dL, reduce to 50 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 7.5 mg/dL, do not use
Renal Impairment
  • Cyclophosphamide:
    If CrCl 10-50 mL/min, reduce dose by 25%
    If CrCl < 10 mL/min, reduce dose by 50%
  • Doxorubicin:
    No dose reduction
  • Paclitaxel:
    No dose reduction

    If AST and ALT < 10 upper normal limit, and bilirubin 1.5-3 upper normal limit, use 20-30 mg/m2
    If AST or ALT > 10 upper normal limit, or bilirubin > 3 upper normal limit, do not use
    In combination with capecitabine:
    If AST and ALT < 2.5 upper normal limit, and bilirubin < 1 upper normal limit, use 40 mg/m2
    If AST or ALT > 2.5 upper normal limit, or bilirubin > 1 upper normal limit, do not use

    If transaminase 2-10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.5 mg/dL, reduce to 100 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.6-7.5 mg/dL, reduce to 50 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 7.5 mg/dL, do not use
Renal Impairment
  • Carboplatin:
    Dosing based on AUC
  • Gemcitabine:
    No dose reduction
  • paclitaxel:
    No dose reduction

regimen.name: Hyper-CVAD/MTX-Ara-C

Doxorubicin 50 mg/m2 over 48 hours after cyclophosphamide, days 4-5
Vincristine 2 mg administered 12 hours after last cyclophosphamide dose, repeated on day 11
Dexamethasone 40 mg/d IV or PO,days 1-4,11-14
Filgrastim 5 mcg/kg IV or SQ beginning 24 hours after doxorubicin is complete.
COURSE 2
(BEGIN AFTER CLINICAL AND HEMATOLOGIC RECOVERY FROM COURSE 1)
Methotrexate 200 mg/m2 IV bolus, day 1
FOLLOWED BY
Methotrexate 800mg/m2over 24 hours day1 Followed by
Cytarabine3000 mg/m2 IV every 12 hours for 4 doses, days 2-3 (dose reduced to 1,000 mg/m2 in patients >60 years or with serum creatinine >1.5 mg/dL)

FOLLOWED 6 HOURS LATER BY
Leucovorin calcium 15 mg PO every 6 hours for 8 doses (dose adjusted for Methotrexate concentration at 24 and 48 hours after completion of Methotrexate infusion)
Filgrastim 5mcg/kg IV or SQ begining 24 hours after cytarabine.
Repeat courses every 21 days.

regimen.name: Carbo/VP-16/Vincristine
regimen.schedule:
CYCLES 1 AND 3 (3-WEEK CYCLES)

Etoposide 100 mg/m2 IV, days 1-3
Carboplatin 500 mg/m2 IV, days 1, 2

CYCLES 2 AND 4 (3-WEEK CYCLES)
Vincristined 1.5 mg/m2 IV, days 1, 7, 14
Etoposide 100 mg/m2 IV, days 1-3
Cyclophosphamide 1,500 mg/m2 IV, day 1
Mesna 750 mg/m2 IV, 15 minutes before and 4 and 8 hours after cyclophosphamide
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment
  • Carboplatin:
    No dose reduction
  • Cyclophosphamide:
    If bilirubin 3-5 mg/dL or SGOT > 180 mg/dL, reduce dose by 25%
    If bilirubin >5 mg/dL, do not use
  • Etoposide:
    If bilirubin 1.5-3 mg/dL or SGOT 60-180 mg/dL, reduce dose by 50%
    If bilirubin > 3 mg/dL or SGOT > 180 mg/dL, do not use
  • Mesna:
    No dose reduction
  • Vincristine:
    If bilirubin 1.5-3 mg/dL or SGOT 60-180 mg/dL, reduce dose by 50%
    If bilirubin > 3 mg/dL or SGOT > 180 mg/dL, do not use
Renal Impairment
  • Carboplatin:
    Dosing based on AUC
  • Cyclophosphamide:
    If CrCl 10-50 mL/min, reduce dose by 25%
    If CrCl < 10 mL/min, reduce dose by 50%
  • Etoposide:
    If CrCl 10-50 mL/min, reduce dose by 25%
    If CrCl < 10 mL/min, reduce dose by 50%
  • Vincristine:
    No dose reduction

references.referenceValue: Taylor RE, Bailey CC, Robinson K, et al. Results of a randomized study of preradiation chemotherapy versus radiotherapy alone for nonmetastatic medulloblastoma: the International Society of Paediatric Oncology/United Kingdom Children's Cancer Study Group PNET-3 study.

regimen.name: VAD
regimen.schedule:

Dactinomycin 1.5 mg/m2 IV every 6 weeks for 26 weeks
ALTERNATING WITH
Doxorubicin 40 mg/m2 IV every 6 weeks for 1 year (stage III)
OR
Vincristine 1.5 mg/m2 IV, day 1
Dactinomycin 15 mcg/kg/d IV, days 1-5 or 60 mcg/kg IV, day 1
Repeat every 6 weeks; if stage III or IV, add:
Doxorubicin 20 mg/m2 IV, day 1, and RT

  • Doxorubicin:

    If bilirubin >5 mg/dL, do not use
  • Vincristine:

    If bilirubin > 3 mg/dL or SGOT > 180 mg/dL, do not use
Renal Impairment
  • Doxorubicin:
    No dose reduction
  • Vincristine:
    No dose reduction

regimen.schedule:
Oxaliplatin: 100 mg/m2 IV on day 1

5-Fluorouracil: 400 mg/m2 IV bolus on day 1, followed by 2,400 mg/m2 IV continuous infusion for 46 hours

Leucovorin: 400 mg/m2 IV on day 1 as a 2-hour infusion before 5-fluorouracil

Repeat cycle every 2 weeks

Chemotherapy

  • Cisplatin (Platinol) 35 mg/m2 IV once per day on days 1 & 8
  • Gemcitabine (Gemzar) 1000 mg/m2 IV once per day on days 1 & 8

21-day cycle for 4 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Myelotoxicity
  • Each cycle should not begin until the WBC is ≥3000/microL and platelet count is ≥100,000/microL.Gemcitabine should be withheld on day 8 and/or day 15 of the scheduled treatment if the WBC is <2000/microL or the platelet count is <50,000/microL. If the day 8 or 15 dose of gemcitabine is omitted, the treatment cycle may be shortened to 21 days.
Neurologic toxicity
  • Neuropathy usually is seen with cumulative doses of cisplatin >400 mg/m2, although there is marked interindividual variation. Patients with mild neuropathy can continue to receive full cisplatin doses. However, if the neuropathy interferes with function, the risk of potentially disabling neurotoxicity must be weighed against the benefit of continued treatment.
Pulmonary toxicity
  • A variety of manifestations of pulmonary toxicity have been reported. Discontinue gemcitabine immediately and permanently.
Hepatotoxicity
  • Gemcitabine is commonly associated with a transient rise in serum transaminases, but these are seldom of clinical significance. There is insufficient information from clinical studies to allow clear dose recommendations in these patients.
Nephrotoxicity
  • Hold cisplatin until serum creatinine <1.5 mg/dL and/or blood urea nitrogen <25 mg/dL. For grade ≥2 nephrotoxicity during treatment (creatinine >1.5 times normal value despite adequate hydration), creatinine clearance should be determined prior to next cycle, and cisplatin dose reduced if <60 mL/min.
Thrombotic microangiopathy
  • Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA, also sometimes called thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura [TTP] or hemolytic uremic syndrome [HUS]) has been associated with gemcitabine, in individuals who have received a large or small cumulative dose. Consider the possibility of TMA if the patient develops Coombs-negative hemolysis, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, and/or neurologic findings. Management consists of drug discontinuation and supportive care, without plasma exchange, as long as there is high confidence in a drug-induced etiology rather than TTP.

references.referenceValue: Dash A, Pettus JA 4th, Herr HW, Bochner BH, Dalbagni G, Donat SM, Russo P, Boyle MG, Milowsky MI, Bajorin DF. A role for neoadjuvant gemcitabine plus cisplatin in muscle-invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder: a retrospective experience. Cancer. 2008 Nov 1;113(9):2471-7.

21-day cycles
regimen.dosageModifications: none

references.referenceValue: Balar AV, Galsky MD, Rosenberg JE, Powles T, Petrylak DP, Bellmunt J, Loriot Y, Necchi A, Hoffman-Censits J, Perez-Gracia JL, Dawson NA, van der Heijden MS, Dreicer R, Srinivas S, Retz MM, Joseph RW, Drakaki A, Vaishampayan UN, Sridhar SS, Quinn DI, Durán I, Shaffer DR, Eigl BJ, Grivas PD, Yu EY, Li S, Kadel EE 3rd, Boyd Z, Bourgon R, Hegde PS, Mariathasan S, Thåström A, Abidoye OO, Fine GD, Bajorin DF; IMvigor210 Study Group. Atezolizumab as first-line treatment in cisplatin-ineligible patients with locally advanced and metastatic urothelial carcinoma: a single-arm, multicentre, phase 2 trial. Lancet. 2017 Jan 7;389(10064):67-76. Epub 2016 Dec 8.

regimen.schedule:
Binimetinib: 45 mg PO twice daily

Encorafenib: 300 mg PO daily

Cetuximab: 400 mg/m2 IV loading dose, then 250 mg/m2 IV weekly

Continue treatment until disease progression. Use only for patients with BRAF V600E-mutant mCRC.

Variant 1: -- 3 or 4 cycles 

Chemotherapy

  • Methotrexate (MTX) 30 mg/m2 IV over 30 minutes once on day 1
  • Vinblastine (Velban) 3 mg/m2 IV push once on day 2
  • Doxorubicin (Adriamycin) 30 mg/m2 IV push once on day 2
  • Cisplatin (Platinol) 70 mg/m2 IV in 1 liter normal saline once on day 2
    • Split dose could be used at physician discretion for patients with CrCl less than 60 mL/min/1.73m2: 35 mg/m2 IV once per day on days 1 & 2

Supportive medications

  • Pegfilgrastim (Neulasta) 6 mg SC once, 24 to 48 hours after completion of chemotherapy
  • Antiemetics used often included Aprepitant (Emend), Ondansetron (Zofran), and Dexamethasone (Decadron) but were not specified by the trial.

14-day cycle for 3 or 4 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Myelotoxicity
  • Delay treatment cycle until the WBC count is >3000/mm3 and platelet count is >90,000 mm3. Methotrexate and doxorubicin doses should be reduced by 33% in patients who have a nadir WBC <2000/mm3.
Neurologic toxicity
  • Cisplatin therapy should be discontinued when neurologic symptoms are first observed. The manufacturer recommends a dose reduction of vinblastine by 1 mg/m2 in patients with severe neurotoxicity.
  • For severe paresthesias and/or constipation, the dose of vinblastine should be reduced by 50%. Vinblastine should be discontinued permanently if an adynamic ileus occurs.
Mucositis
  • Doses of methotrexate should be reduced by 33% in patients who develop grade 3 or grade 4 mucositis.
Cardiotoxicity
  • Discontinue doxorubicin in patients who develop signs/symptoms of cardiomyopathy.
  • Monitor cumulative doxorubicin dose and reassess LVEF periodically during MVAC therapy as clinically indicated.
Renal dysfunction
  • Hold cisplatin until serum creatinine <1.5 mg/dL or CrCl >55 mL/min and/or BUN <25 mg/dL.

Chemotherapy

  • Cisplatin (Platinol) 35 mg/m2 IV once per day on days 1 & 8
  • Gemcitabine (Gemzar) 1000 mg/m2 IV once per day on days 1 & 8

21-day cycle for 4 cycles

Immunotherapy

21-day cycles

references.referenceValue: KEYNOTE-052: Balar AV, Castellano D, O'Donnell PH, Grivas P, Vuky J, Powles T, Plimack ER, Hahn NM, de Wit R, Pang L, Savage MJ, Perini RF, Keefe SM, Bajorin D, Bellmunt J. First-line pembrolizumab in cisplatin-ineligible patients with locally advanced and unresectable or metastatic urothelial cancer (KEYNOTE-052): a multicentre, single-arm, phase 2 study. Lancet Oncol. 2017 Nov;18(11):1483-1492. Epub 2017 Sep 26.

regimen.schedule:
Chemotherapy

  • Gemcitabine (Gemzar) 2500 mg/m2 IV over 30 minutes once on day 1, given second
  • Paclitaxel (Taxol) 150 mg/m2 IV over 3 hours once on day 1, given first

14-day cycle for 6 to 12 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Myelotoxicity
  • Do not administer paclitaxel and gemcitabine on day 1 of each new cycle unless ANC is >1500/microL and platelet count is >100,000/microL. For patients who develop neutropenic fever OR ANC <500/microL for >7 days or delay of next cycle by >7 days or thrombocytopenia, withhold treatment until counts recover to an ANC of at least 1500/microL and platelet count of at least 100,000/microL on day 1, or to an ANC of at least 500/microL and platelet count of at least 50,000/microL on days 8 or 15 of the cycle. Upon resumption of therapy, reduce both drugs by 20 to 25% upon the first occurrence, an additional 20 to 25% on the second recurrence, and discontinue treatment for a third occurrence.
Sepsis
  • Sepsis has occurred in patients with or without neutropenia (risk factors are biliary obstruction or presence of a biliary stent). Initiate broad-spectrum antibiotics in the presence of fever, even if not neutropenic. Interrupt paclitaxel and gemcitabine until sepsis resolves and, if neutropenic, until neutrophils are at least 1500/microL, then resume at lower doses.
Thrombotic microangiopathy
  • Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA; also sometimes called thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura [TTP] or hemolytic uremic syndrome [HUS]) has been associated with gemcitabine in individuals who have received a large or small cumulative dose. Consider the possibility of TMA if the patient develops Coombs-negative hemolysis, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, and/or neurologic findings. Management consists of drug discontinuation and supportive care, without plasma exchange, as long as there is high confidence in a drug-induced etiology rather than TTP.
Peripheral neuropathy
  • For days 1,8, and 15: withhold paclitaxel for grade 3 or 4 neuropathy. Resume paclitaxel at 20 to 25 percent reduced doses when peripheral neuropathy improves to grade ≤2 or completely resolves . Upon resumption of therapy, reduce paclitaxel by 20 to 25% for the first occurrence of grade 3 or 4 peripheral neuropathy, and an additional 20 to 25% for the second occurrence. Discontinue treatment for a third occurrence. For grade 2 peripheral neuropathy, decrease paclitaxel dose by 20 to 25%.
Hepatotoxicity
  • Gemcitabine is commonly associated with a transient rise in serum transaminases, but these are seldom of clinical significance. There is insufficient information from clinical studies to allow clear gemcitabine dose recommendations in these patients.
  • Reduced starting doses of paclitaxel are recommended for individuals with pre-existing moderate to severe hepatic impairment; the need for further dose adjustments in subsequent courses based upon ongoing hepatotoxicity should be based on individual tolerance and clinician judgment.
  • One protocol recommends the following: on days 1, 8, and 15, for serum bilirubin elevations ≥grade 2, withhold both drugs until toxicity resolves to grade ≤1; resume treatment at the same dose as before. If not resolved, discontinue therapy.
Pulmonary toxicity
  • A variety of manifestations of pulmonary toxicity have been reported with gemcitabine. Pneumonitis has occurred with the use of paclitaxel in combination with gemcitabine. Permanently discontinue treatment with both agents.
Other toxicity
  • On days 1, 8, and 15: for grade 3 cutaneous toxicity, hold both drugs until recovered to ≤grade 2, and reduce paclitaxel dose by 20 to 25% and gemcitabine dose by 20%. For grade 3 mucositis or diarrhea, withhold therapy until it improves to ≤grade 1, then resume with reduction of paclitaxel dose by 20 to 25% and gemcitabine dose by 20%.

references.referenceValue: Calabrò F, Lorusso V, Rosati G, Manzione L, Frassineti L, Sava T, Di Paula ED, Alonso S, Sternberg CN. Gemcitabine and paclitaxel every 2 weeks in patients with previously untreated urothelial carcinoma. Cancer. 2009 Jun 15;115(12):2652-9

  • Gemcitabine (Gemzar) 1000 mg/m2 IV once per day on days 1, 8, 15
  • Paclitaxel (Taxol) 200 mg/m2 IV over 3 hours once on day 1

    • The FDA-approved dose which is listed in the package insert is 240 mg IV over 60 minutes once on day 1

14-day cycles

regimen.schedule:
Chemotherapy

  • Paclitaxel (Taxol) 175 mg/m2 IV once on day 1

21-day cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment

Transaminases <10 times ULN and bilirubin level ≤1.25 times ULN: 175 mg/m2

Transaminases <10 times ULN and bilirubin level 1.26 to 2 times ULN: 135 mg/m2

Transaminases <10 times ULN and bilirubin level 2.01 to 5 times ULN: 90 mg/m2

Transaminases ≥10 times ULN or bilirubin level >5 times ULN: Avoid use
Renal Impairement none
Myelosuppression Courses of paclitaxel should not be repeated until the neutrophil count is ≥1,500/mm3 and the platelet count is ≥100,000/mm3; reduce dosage by 20% for patients experiencing severe peripheral neuropathy or severe neutropenia (neutrophil <500/mm3 for a week or longer)

references.referenceValue: Bellmunt J, de Wit R, Vaughn DJ, Fradet Y, Lee JL, Fong L, Vogelzang NJ, Climent MA, Petrylak DP, Choueiri TK, Necchi A, Gerritsen W, Gurney H, Quinn DI, Culine S, Sternberg CN, Mai Y, Poehlein CH, Perini RF, Bajorin DF; KEYNOTE-045 Investigators. Pembrolizumab as second-line therapy for advanced urothelial carcinoma. N Engl J Med. 2017 Mar 16;376(11):1015-1026. Epub 2017 Feb 17

regimen.schedule:
Chemotherapy

  • Carboplatin (Paraplatin) AUC 5 IV over 30 to 60 minutes once on day 2
  • Gemcitabine (Gemzar) 1250 mg/m2 IV over 30 to 60 minutes once per day on days 1 & 8

21-day cycle for up to 6 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Myelotoxicity
  • Chemotherapy should be delayed for one week if the ANC is <1000/microL and/or the platelet count is <75,000/microL prior to the start of each cycle. Doses for subsequent cycles are reduced by 25% if the ANC is 1000 to 1499/microL or platelets are 75,000 to 99,000/microL on day 22 after the preceding cycle, or if the nadir ANC was <500/microL. A 50% dose reduction should be considered if the platelet nadir is <50,000/microL. Consider discontinuing therapy if a patient qualifies for a third dose reduction or a cycle is delayed by more than 21 days.
  • Omissions or reductions of the gemcitabine dose on day 8 of a cycle are allowed and are based upon the same criteria as on day 1. Dose reductions should be maintained for subsequent cycles.
Thrombotic microangiopathy
  • Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA, also sometimes called thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura [TTP] or hemolytic uremic syndrome [HUS]) has been associated with gemcitabine, in individuals who have received a large or small cumulative dose. Consider the possibility of TMA if the patient develops Coombs-negative hemolysis, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, and/or neurologic findings. Management consists of drug discontinuation and supportive care, without plasma exchange, as long as there is high confidence in a drug-induced etiology rather than TTP.
Pulmonary toxicity
  • A variety of manifestations of pulmonary toxicity have been reported. Discontinue gemcitabine immediately and permanently.
Other nonhematologic toxicity§
  • Creatinine clearance should be ≥45 mL/min and grade 3 or 4 toxicities should be resolved prior to beginning therapy. A delay in therapy by one week should be considered if toxicities are not resolved or the creatinine clearance ≤45 mL/min. It is recommended that subsequent cycles be dose reduced by 25% if the patient has grade 3 or 4 toxicity (excluding grade 3 or 4 mucositis, in which a 50% dose reduction is warranted) and discontinued if a patient qualifies for a third dose reduction or a cycle is delayed by more than 21 days.
  • Omissions or reductions of the gemcitabine dose on day 8 of a cycle are allowed. Dose reductions should be maintained for subsequent cycles.

references.referenceValue: Dogliotti L, Cartenì G, Siena S, Bertetto O, Martoni A, Bono A, Amadori D, Onat H, Marini L. Gemcitabine plus cisplatin versus gemcitabine plus carboplatin as first-line chemotherapy in advanced transitional cell carcinoma of the urothelium: results of a randomized phase 2 trial. Eur Urol. 2007 Jul;52(1):134-41. Epub 2006 Dec 26

regimen.schedule:
Nivolumab: 3 mg/kg IV on day 1

Ipilimumab: 1 mg/kg IV on day 1

Repeat cycle every 21 days for 4 cycles and then treat with nivolumab at 3 mg/kg or 240 mg IV every 14 days until disease progression or toxicity.

Chemotherapy

  • Docetaxel (Taxotere) 75 mg/m2 IV once on day 1

21-day cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Myelotoxicity
  • Docetaxel should only be administered if the absolute neutrophil count is >1500 cells/microL. Reduce docetaxel to 60 mg/m2 for subsequent cycles for severe prolonged neutropenia (<500 cells/microL lasting seven days or more), febrile neutropenia, or an infection with life-threatening consequences.
Cutaneous, mucosal, and neurologic toxicity
  • For severe or cumulative cutaneous reactions (erythema, desquamation), grade 3 or 4 stomatitis or >grade 2 neurosensory signs and/or symptoms, reduce docetaxel dose to 60 mg/m2 Discontinue docetaxel if toxicity persists at the lower dose.
Hepatotoxicity
  • Docetaxel dose reduction may be needed for patients who develop significant alterations in transaminases and alkaline phosphatase during therapy. Docetaxel should not be administered to patients with a serum bilirubin above the ULN or to patients with transaminase elevations >1.5 times the ULN in conjunction with alkaline phosphatase >2.5 times the ULN.

regimen.schedule:
Biomarker eligibility criteria

  • Alterations: FGFR3 mutation, FGFR2 fusion, or FGFR3 fusion

Chemotherapy

  • Erdafitinib (Balversa) 8 mg PO once per day
    • If serum phosphorus level and tolerability are acceptable at days 14 to 21, increase to 9 mg PO once per day
    • Additional dose adjustments per package insert
regimen.dosageModifications:
Renal Impairement none
Hepatic Impairement none

Dose at the time of toxicity: 8 mg once daily.

First dose reduction level: 6 mg once daily.

Second dose reduction level: 5 mg once daily.

Third dose reduction level: 4 mg once daily.

Discontinue if unable to tolerate 4 mg once daily.

 

Hyperphosphatemia: Note: Restrict phosphate intake to 600 to 800 mg daily; if serum phosphate is >7 mg/dL, consider initiating an oral phosphate binder until phosphate level is <5.5 mg/dL.

Phosphate level 5.6 to 6.9 mg/dL: Continue erdafitinib at current dose.

Phosphate level 7 to 9 mg/dL: Interrupt erdafitinib therapy and assess serum phosphate weekly; when level is <5.5 mg/dL (or baseline), reinitiate erdafitinib at the same dose. If hyperphosphatemia persisted for >1 week, consider dose reduction.

Phosphate level >9 mg/dL: Interrupt erdafitinib therapy and assess serum phosphate weekly; when level is <5.5 mg/dL (or baseline), may reinitiate erdafitinib at the next lower dose level.

Phosphate level >10 mg/dL, or significant alteration in baseline renal function, or grade 3 hypercalcemia: Interrupt erdafitinib therapy and assess serum phosphate weekly; when level is <5.5 mg/dL (or baseline), may reinitiate erdafitinib at 2 dose levels lower.
Ocular toxicity (central serous retinopathy/retinal pigment epithelial detachment)

Grade 1 (asymptomatic; clinical or diagnostic observations only): Interrupt erdafitinib therapy until resolution; if resolves within 4 weeks, reinitiate erdafitinib at the next lower dose level. If no recurrence for one month, may consider re-escalating the dose. If central serous retinopathy/retinal pigment epithelial detachment is stable for 2 consecutive eye exams (but not resolved), reinitiate erdafitinib at the next lower dose level.

Grade 2 (visual acuity ≥20/40 or ≤3 lines of decreased vision from baseline): Interrupt erdafitinib therapy until resolution; if resolves within 4 weeks, may reinitiate erdafitinib at the next lower dose level.

Grade 3 (visual acuity <20/40 or >3 lines of decreased vision from baseline): Interrupt erdafitinib therapy until resolution; if resolves within 4 weeks, may reinitiate erdafitinib at 2 dose levels lower. If grade 3 toxicity recurs, consider permanent discontinuation.

Grade 4 (visual acuity ≤20/200 in affected eye): Permanently discontinue erdafitinib.

Dry eye symptoms: Administer dry eye prophylaxis (with ocular demulcents) as needed.
Other toxicity:

Grade 3: Interrupt erdafitinib therapy until improvement to grade 1 or baseline, then may reinitiate at the next lower dose level.

Grade 4: Permanently discontinue erdafitinib.

references.referenceValue: BLC2001: Loriot Y, Necchi A, Park SH, Garcia-Donas J, Huddart R, Burgess E, Fleming M, Rezazadeh A, Mellado B, Varlamov S, Joshi M, Duran I, Tagawa ST, Zakharia Y, Zhong B, Stuyckens K, Santiago-Walker A, De Porre P, O'Hagan A, Avadhani A, Siefker-Radtke AO; BLC2001 Study Group. Erdafitinib in locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma. N Engl J Med. 2019 Jul 25;381(4):338-348.

regimen.schedule:
Chemotherapy

  • Carboplatin (Paraplatin) AUC 4.5 IV over 60 minutes once on day 1, given second
  • Gemcitabine (Gemzar) 1000 mg/m2 IV over 30 minutes once per day on days 1 & 8, given first

21-day cycles

Patients who achieved complete response were given two additional cycles of treatment.
regimen.dosageModifications:
Myelotoxicity
  • Chemotherapy should be delayed for one week if the ANC is <1000/microL and/or the platelet count is <75,000/microL prior to the start of each cycle. Doses for subsequent cycles are reduced by 25% if the ANC is 1000 to 1499/microL or platelets are 75,000 to 99,000/microL on day 22 after the preceding cycle, or if the nadir ANC was <500/microL. A 50% dose reduction should be considered if the platelet nadir is <50,000/microL. Consider discontinuing therapy if a patient qualifies for a third dose reduction or a cycle is delayed by more than 21 days.
  • Omissions or reductions of the gemcitabine dose on day 8 of a cycle are allowed and are based upon the same criteria as on day 1. Dose reductions should be maintained for subsequent cycles.
Thrombotic microangiopathy
  • Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA, also sometimes called thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura [TTP] or hemolytic uremic syndrome [HUS]) has been associated with gemcitabine, in individuals who have received a large or small cumulative dose. Consider the possibility of TMA if the patient develops Coombs-negative hemolysis, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, and/or neurologic findings. Management consists of drug discontinuation and supportive care, without plasma exchange, as long as there is high confidence in a drug-induced etiology rather than TTP.
Pulmonary toxicity
  • A variety of manifestations of pulmonary toxicity have been reported. Discontinue gemcitabine immediately and permanently.
Other nonhematologic toxicity§
  • Creatinine clearance should be ≥45 mL/min and grade 3 or 4 toxicities should be resolved prior to beginning therapy. A delay in therapy by one week should be considered if toxicities are not resolved or the creatinine clearance ≤45 mL/min. It is recommended that subsequent cycles be dose reduced by 25% if the patient has grade 3 or 4 toxicity (excluding grade 3 or 4 mucositis, in which a 50% dose reduction is warranted) and discontinued if a patient qualifies for a third dose reduction or a cycle is delayed by more than 21 days.
  • Omissions or reductions of the gemcitabine dose on day 8 of a cycle are allowed. Dose reductions should be maintained for subsequent cycles.

regimen.dosageModifications:
Renal Impairment none
Hepatic Impairment none

 

Recommended Enfortumab Vedotin Dosage Reduction Levels

Initial (usual) dose

1.25 mg/kg up to a maximum of 125 mg

First dose reduction level

1 mg/kg up to a maximum of 100 mg

Second dose reduction level

0.75 mg/kg up to a maximum of 75 mg

Third dosage reduction level

0.5 mg/kg up to a maximum of 50 mg

Enfortumab Vedotin Dosage Adjustment for Toxicities

Toxicity

Severitya

Enfortumab Vedotin Dose Modification

aGrade 1 is mild, grade 2 is moderate, grade 3 is severe, and grade 4 is life-threatening.

Hematologic toxicities

Grade 3, or grade 2 thrombocytopenia

Withhold enfortumab vedotin until ≤ grade 1, then resume treatment at the same dose level or consider dose reduction by 1 dose level.

Grade 4

Withhold enfortumab vedotin until ≤ grade 1, then reduce dose by 1 dose level or discontinue treatment.

Hyperglycemia

Blood glucose >250 mg/dL

Withhold enfortumab vedotin until elevated blood glucose has improved to ≤250 mg/dL, then resume treatment at the same dose level.

Peripheral neuropathy

Grade 2

Withhold enfortumab vedotin until ≤ grade 1, then resume treatment at the same dose level (if first occurrence). For a recurrence, withhold until ≤ grade 1, then resume treatment with the dose reduced by one dose level.

Grade 3 or higher

Permanently discontinue enfortumab vedotin.

Dermatologic toxicity (skin reactions)

Grade 3 (severe)

Withhold enfortumab vedotin until ≤ grade 1, then resume treatment at the same dose level or consider dose reduction by 1 dose level.

Grade 4 or recurrent grade 3

Permanently discontinue enfortumab vedotin.

Other nonhematologic toxicity

Grade 3

Withhold enfortumab vedotin until ≤ grade 1, then resume treatment at the same dose level or consider dose reduction by 1 dose level.

Grade 4

Permanently discontinue enfortumab vedotin.

regimen.schedule:
Pembrolizumab 200 mg IV given on day 1 at least 30 minutes prior to chemotherapy
Pemetrexed 500mg/m2 given on day 1 
Cisplatin 75 mg/m2 given on day 1

Administer in 21 day cycles for 4 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Pembrolizumab

Renal Impairment:

Prior to treatment initiation: No dosage adjustment necessary. 

During treatment:

  • Grade 2: Withhold pembrolizumab; administer corticosteroids (prednisone 1-2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent] followed by a taper); may resume upon recovery to grade 0 or 1 toxicity.

  • Grade 3 or 4: Permanently discontinue pembrolizumab; administer corticosteroids (prednisone 1-2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent] followed by a taper).

Hepatic Impairment:

Prior to treatment initiation: 

  • No dosage adjustment necessary for mild impairment (Bilirubin ≤ ULN and AST > ULN OR bilirubin >1 - 1.5 × ULN and any AST).
  • No dosage adjustments provided in manufacturer’s labeling for moderate to severe impairment.

During treatment:

  • Patients without hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) or Renal Cell Carcinoma(RCC) also receiving axitinib:

    • Grade 2 hepatitis: Administer corticosteroids (prednisone 0.5 - 1 mg/kg/day [or equivalent]).

    • Grade 3 or higher hepatitis: prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent], followed by a taper). Withhold or discontinue therapy based on the severity of liver enzyme elevations:

      • AST or ALT 3 - 5x ULN or bilirubin 1.5 – 3x ULN: Withhold treatment; may resume therapy upon return to grade 0 or 1 toxicity.

      • AST or ALT >5x ULN or total bilirubin >3x ULN (without liver metastases): Permanently discontinue pembrolizumab.

      • If baseline grade 2 ALT or AST abnormalities with liver metastases, permanently discontinue pembrolizumab if AST or ALT increases by ≥50% from baseline and persists for at least 1 week.

Cisplatin

Renal Impairment:

  • CrCl 10 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose.
  • CrCl <10 mL/minute: Administer 50% of dose.
  • Hemodialysis: Administer 50% of dose posthemodialysis.
  • Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis: Administer 50% of dose.
  • Continuous renal replacement therapy: Administer 75% of dose.

Hepatic Impairment: No Dosage Adjustments 

Pemetrexed

Renal Impairment: 

  • CrCl ≥45 mL/minute: No dosage adjustment necessary. If Cr 45- 79 mL/minute with concomitant use of ibuprofen, avoid ibuprofen 2 days prior to treatment, day of treatment, and 2 days following.

  • CrCl <45 mL/minute: Use is not recommended by the manufacturer (has not been studied sufficiently)

Hepatic Impairment: No dosage instructions are provided in manufacturer's labeling

regimen.schedule:
Doxorubicin 60mg/m2 IV on day 1
Cyclophosphamide 600mg/m2 IV on day 1

Repeat every 21 days for 4 cycles.

FOLLOWED BY

regimen.emetogenicPotential: High for AC, low for paclitaxel and trastuzumab
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment

  • Cyclophosphamide:
    If bilirubin 3-5 mg/dL or SGOT > 180 mg/dL, reduce dose by 25%
    If bilirubin > 5 mg/dL, do not use
  • Doxorubicin:
    If bilirubin 1.2-3 mg/dL, reduce dose by 50%
    If bilirubin 3.1-5 mg/dL, reduce dose by 75%
    If bilirubin > 5 mg/dL, do not use
  • Paclitaxel:
    For 3-hour infusion:
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.25 upper normal limit, no dose reduction (175mg/m2)
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.26-2 upper normal limit, reduce to 135 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 2.01-5 upper normal limit, reduce to 90 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 5 upper normal limit, do not use
    For 24-hour infusion:
    If transaminase < 2 upper normal limit or bilirubin < 1.5 mg/mL, no dose reduction (135 mg/m2)
    If transaminase 2-10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.5 mg/dL, reduce to 100 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.6-7.5 mg/dL, reduce to 50 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 7.5 mg/dL, do not use

Renal Impairment

  • Cyclophosphamide:
    If CrCl 10-50 mL/min, reduce dose by 25%
    If CrCl < 10 mL/min, reduce dose by 50%
  • Doxorubicin:
    No dose reduction
  • Paclitaxel:
    No dose reduction

regimen.dosageModifications:
Cisplatin

Hepatic

  • No Dosage Adjustments

Renal

  • CrCl 10 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose.
  • CrCl <10 mL/minute: Administer 50% of dose.
  • Hemodialysis: Administer 50% of dose posthemodialysis.
  • Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis: Administer 50% of dose.
  • Continuous renal replacement therapy: Administer 75% of dose.

Etoposide:

Hepatic

  • No dose adjustments in manufacturers labeling
  • Per Hendrayana, Wilmer, Kurth et al, 2017:
    • T.Bil 1.5–3 mg/dL or AST 60–180: 50% of of full dose
    • T.Bil ≥ 3 mg/dL or AST > 180: omit

Renal

  • CrCl >50 mL/minute: No adjustment required.
  • CrCl 15 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose
  • CrCl <15 mL minute: No data available; consider further dose reductions

regimen.schedule:
Carboplatin AUC 5-6 day 1 OR 75-80mg/m2

Every 21 days for maximum of 4 cycles

regimen.dosageModifications:
Carboplatin

Renal: AUC dosing 

  • Hemodialysis: hemodialysis should occur between 12 to 24 hours after carboplatin dose

Hepatic: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling

Etoposide:

Hepatic: No dose adjustments in manufacturers labeling

Hendrayana, Wilmer, Kurth et al, 2017:

  • T.Bil 1.5–3 mg/dL or AST 60–180: 50% of of full dose
  • T.Bil ≥ 3 mg/dL or AST > 180: omit

Renal:

  • CrCl >50 mL/minute: No adjustment required.
  • CrCl 15 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose
  • CrCl <15 mL minute: No data available; consider further dose reductions

Etoposide:

Hepatic: No dose adjustments in manufacturers labeling

Hendrayana, Wilmer, Kurth et al, 2017:

  • T.Bil 1.5–3 mg/dL or AST 60–180: 50% of of full dose
  • T.Bil ≥ 3 mg/dL or AST > 180: omit

Renal

  • CrCl >50 mL/minute: No adjustment required.
  • CrCl 15 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose
  • CrCl <15 mL minute: No data available; consider further dose reductions

Durvalumab

Hepatic:

Hepatic impairment prior to treatment initiation:

  • There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

Hepatotoxicity during treatment:

  • ALT or AST >3 - 8 x ULN or total bilirubin >1.5 - 5 x ULN: Withhold dose. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone initial dose of 1 to 2 mg/kg/day or equivalent) with subsequent taper. May resume when hepatitis has improved to grade 1 or resolved and corticosteroid dose is ≤10 mg/day prednisone (or equivalent).
  • ALT or AST >8 times ULN or total bilirubin >5 times ULN: Discontinue permanently. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone initial dose of 1 to 2 mg/kg daily or equivalent) with subsequent taper. 
  • Concurrent ALT or AST >3 x ULN and total bilirubin >2 x ULN without alternate cause: Discontinue permanently. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone initial dose of 1 to 2 mg/kg/day or equivalent) with subsequent taper. 

Renal:

Renal toxicity prior to initiation of treatment (nephritis):

  • There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

Renal toxicity during treatment (nephritis):

  • Creatinine >1.5 - 3x ULN: Withhold dose. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone initial dose of 1 - 2 mg/kg/day or equivalent) followed by a taper. May resume durvalumab when nephritis has improved to grade 1 or resolved and corticosteroid dose is ≤10 mg/day prednisone (or equivalent).
  • Creatinine >3x ULN: Discontinue permanently. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone initial dose of 1 to 2 mg/kg daily or equivalent) with subsequent taper.

regimen.schedule:
Cisplatin 75-80 mg/m2 on day 1
Etoposide 80-100 mg/m2 on days 1, 2, 3 
Durvalumab 1,500 mg on day 1

Repeat cycle every 21 days x 4 cycles 

Followed by maintenance durvalumab 1,500 mg on day one, repeat cycle every 28 days
regimen.dosageModifications:
Cisplatin

Hepatic:

  • No Dosage Adjustments

Renal:

  • CrCl 10 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose.
  • CrCl <10 mL/minute: Administer 50% of dose.
  • Hemodialysis: Administer 50% of dose posthemodialysis.
  • Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis: Administer 50% of dose.
  • Continuous renal replacement therapy: Administer 75% of dose.

Etoposide:

Hepatic: No dose adjustments in manufacturers labeling

Hendrayana, Wilmer, Kurth et al, 2017:

  • T.Bil 1.5–3 mg/dL or AST 60–180: 50% of of full dose
  • T.Bil ≥ 3 mg/dL or AST > 180: omit

Renal:

  • CrCl >50 mL/minute: No adjustment required.
  • CrCl 15 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose
  • CrCl <15 mL minute: No data available; consider further dose reductions

Etoposide:

Hepatic: No dose adjustments in manufacturers labeling

Hendrayana, Wilmer, Kurth et al, 2017:

  • T.Bil 1.5–3 mg/dL or AST 60–180: 50% of of full dose
  • T.Bil ≥ 3 mg/dL or AST > 180: omit

Renal

  • CrCl >50 mL/minute: No adjustment required.
  • CrCl 15 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose
  • CrCl <15 mL minute: No data available; consider further dose reductions

Durvalumab

Hepatic:

Hepatic impairment prior to treatment initiation:

  • There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

Hepatotoxicity during treatment:

  • ALT or AST >3 - 8 x ULN or total bilirubin >1.5 - 5 x ULN: Withhold dose. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone initial dose of 1 to 2 mg/kg/day or equivalent) with subsequent taper. May resume when hepatitis has improved to grade 1 or resolved and corticosteroid dose is ≤10 mg/day prednisone (or equivalent).
  • ALT or AST >8 times ULN or total bilirubin >5 times ULN: Discontinue permanently. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone initial dose of 1 to 2 mg/kg daily or equivalent) with subsequent taper. 
  • Concurrent ALT or AST >3 x ULN and total bilirubin >2 x ULN without alternate cause: Discontinue permanently. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone initial dose of 1 to 2 mg/kg/day or equivalent) with subsequent taper. 

Renal:

Renal toxicity prior to initiation of treatment (nephritis):

  • There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

Renal toxicity during treatment (nephritis):

  • Creatinine >1.5 - 3x ULN: Withhold dose. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone initial dose of 1 - 2 mg/kg/day or equivalent) followed by a taper. May resume durvalumab when nephritis has improved to grade 1 or resolved and corticosteroid dose is ≤10 mg/day prednisone (or equivalent).
  • Creatinine >3x ULN: Discontinue permanently. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone initial dose of 1 to 2 mg/kg daily or equivalent) with subsequent taper.

Irinotecan

Renal: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling.

  • Dialysis: manufacturer does not recommend use in patients with dialysis.

regimen.schedule:
Capecitabine: 1,250 mg/m2 PO twice daily on days 1-14

Repeat cycle every 21 days. Dose may be decreased to 850-1,000 mg/m2 PO twice daily on days 1-14 to reduce risk of toxicity without compromising clinical efficacy.

CPT-11: 125 mg/m2 IV over 90 minutes weekly for 4 weeks

Repeat cycle every 6 weeks.

OR

Repeat cycle every 3 weeks.

OR

CPT-11: 175 mg/m2 IV on days 1 and 10

Repeat cycle every 3 weeks.

CPT-11: 350 mg/m2 IV on day 1

Repeat cycle every 3 weeks.

Cetuximab: 400 mg/m2 IV loading dose, then 250 mg/m2 IV weekly

Repeat cycle on a weekly basis.

OR

Cetuximab: 500 mg/m2 IV every 2 weeks (no loading dose is necessary)

Repeat cycle every 2 weeks.

Ipilimumab 1 mg/kg IV on day 1
Nivolumab 3 mg/kg IV on day 1, 15, 29

42-day (6 week) cycles for up to 4 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Ipilimumab

Renal Impairment

Prior to treatment: No dosage adjustment necessary.

Renal toxicity (immune mediated nephritis) during treatment:

  • Grade 2 or 3 creatinine elevation: Withhold treatment; administer corticosteroids (prednisone 0.5 - 1 mg/kg/day [or equivalent]) followed by a corticosteroid taper.
    • If toxicity worsens or does not improve, increase corticosteroid dose to prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day (or equivalent).
  • Grade 4 creatinine elevation: Permanently discontinue; administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent]) followed by a corticosteroid taper.

Hepatic Impairment

Prior to treatment:

  • Mild impairment (bilirubin 1 - 1.5 x ULN or AST >ULN): No dosage adjustment necessary.
  • Moderate or severe impairment (total bilirubin >1.5 x ULN and any AST): insufficient data, there are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

Hepatic impairment during treatment:

  • Grade 2: Temporarily withhold treatment.
  • Grade 3 or 4: Permanently discontinue treatment. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent]) followed by 1 month corticosteroid taper when LFTs show sustained improvement or return to baseline.

Nivolumab

Renal Impairment:

  • Creatitine 1.5-6 x ULN- withhold dose
  • Creatinine > 6 x ULN- permanently discontinue

Hepatic Impairment:

  • Transaminases 3 - 5 x ULN or bilirubin 1.5-3 x ULN- withhold dose
  • Transaminases > 5 x ULN or bilirubin > 3 x ULN - permnently discontinue

regimen.schedule:
Pembrolizumab 200 mg IV given on day 1. Administer at least 30 minutes prior to chemotherapy
Carboplatin AUC 5 given on day 1
Pemetrexed 500 mg/m2 IV given on day 1

21-day cycle for 4 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Pembrolizumab

Renal Impairment:

Prior to treatment initiation: No dosage adjustment necessary. 

During treatment:

  • Grade 2: Withhold pembrolizumab; administer corticosteroids (prednisone 1-2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent] followed by a taper); may resume upon recovery to grade 0 or 1 toxicity.

  • Grade 3 or 4: Permanently discontinue pembrolizumab; administer corticosteroids (prednisone 1-2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent] followed by a taper).

Hepatic Impairment:

Prior to treatment initiation: 

  • No dosage adjustment necessary for mild impairment (Bilirubin ≤ ULN and AST > ULN OR bilirubin >1 - 1.5 × ULN and any AST).
  • No dosage adjustments provided in manufacturer’s labeling for moderate to severe impairment.

During treatment:

  • Patients without hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) or Renal Cell Carcinoma(RCC) also receiving axitinib:

    • Grade 2 hepatitis: Administer corticosteroids (prednisone 0.5 - 1 mg/kg/day [or equivalent]).

    • Grade 3 or higher hepatitis: prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent], followed by a taper). Withhold or discontinue therapy based on the severity of liver enzyme elevations:

      • AST or ALT 3 - 5x ULN or bilirubin 1.5 – 3x ULN: Withhold treatment; may resume therapy upon return to grade 0 or 1 toxicity.

      • AST or ALT >5x ULN or total bilirubin >3x ULN (without liver metastases): Permanently discontinue pembrolizumab.

      • If baseline grade 2 ALT or AST abnormalities with liver metastases, permanently discontinue pembrolizumab if AST or ALT increases by ≥50% from baseline and persists for at least 1 week.

Carboplatin

Renal Impairment: AUC dosing

Hemodialysis: hemodialysis should occur between 12 to 24 hours after carboplatin dose

Hepatic Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling

Pemetrexed

Renal Impairment: 

  • CrCl ≥45 mL/minute: No dosage adjustment necessary. If Cr 45- 79 mL/minute with concomitant use of ibuprofen, avoid ibuprofen 2 days prior to treatment, day of treatment, and 2 days following.

  • CrCl <45 mL/minute: Use is not recommended by the manufacturer (has not been studied sufficiently)

Hepatic Impairment:

  • No dosage instructions are provided in manufacturer's labeling

regimen.dosageModifications:
Atezolizumab

Renal

  • eGFR ≥30 mL/minute/1.73 m2: no clinically significant effect on the systemic exposure of atezolizumab. There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.
  • eGFR <30 mL/minute: effect on pharmacokinetics is unknown. There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling (has not been studied).

Hepatic impairment

Prior to treatment:

  • Mild impairment: (bilirubin ≤ ULN and AST > ULN or bilirubin >1 - 1.5 x ULN and any AST): no clinically significant effect on the systemic exposure of atezolizumab and no dosage instructions provided in manufacturer's labeling.
  • Moderate to severe impairment: effect on pharmacokinetics is unknown. There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

During treatment:

AST or ALT >3 - 8 x ULN or bilirubin >1.5 - 3 x ULN: Withhold treatment. Administer corticosteroids (prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day or equivalent) followed by a corticosteroid taper. May resume when ≤ grade 1 toxicity and prednisone dose is ≤10 mg/day (or equivalent).

AST or ALT >8 x ULN or bilirubin >3 x ULN: Discontinue permanently. Administer corticosteroids (prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg daily or equivalent) followed by a corticosteroid taper.

Carboplatin

Renal Impairment: AUC dosing

Hemodialysis: hemodialysis should occur between 12 to 24 hours after carboplatin dose

Hepatic Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling

Paclitaxel

Renal Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling.

Hepatic Impairment:

  • Transaminases <10 x ULN and bilirubin ≤1.25 x ULN: 175 mg/m2
  • Transaminases <10 x ULN and bilirubin 1.26 to 2 x ULN: 135 mg/m2
  • Transaminases <10 x ULN and bilirubin 2.01 to 5 x ULN: 90 mg/m2
  • Transaminases ≥10 x ULN or bilirubin >5 x ULN: Use is not recommended

Bevacizumab

Renal impairment:

Renal impairment prior to treatment: There are no recommended dosage adjustments.

Renal toxicity during treatment:

  • If Proteinuria ≥2 g/24 hours: Withhold bevacizumab until proteinuria <2 g/24 hours. The safety of continued Avastin treatment in patients with moderate to severe proteinuria has not been evaluated
  • Discontinue in patients with nephrotic syndrome.  

Hepatic Impairment: There are no recommended dosage adjustments.

regimen.dosageModifications:
Pembrolizumab

Renal Impairment:

Prior to treatment initiation: No dosage adjustment necessary.

During treatment:

  • Grade 2: Withhold pembrolizumab; administer corticosteroids (prednisone 1-2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent] followed by a taper); may resume upon recovery to grade 0 or 1 toxicity.
  • Grade 3 or 4: Permanently discontinue pembrolizumab; administer corticosteroids (prednisone 1-2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent] followed by a taper).

Hepatic Impairment:

Prior to treatment initiation:

  • No dosage adjustment necessary for mild impairment (Bilirubin ≤ ULN and AST > ULN OR bilirubin >1 - 1.5 × ULN and any AST).
  • No dosage adjustments provided in manufacturer’s labeling for moderate to severe impairment.

During treatment:

  • Patients without hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) or Renal Cell Carcinoma(RCC) also receiving axitinib:
    • Grade 2 hepatitis: Administer corticosteroids (prednisone 0.5 - 1 mg/kg/day [or equivalent]).
    • Grade 3 or higher hepatitis: prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent], followed by a taper). Withhold or discontinue therapy based on the severity of liver enzyme elevations:
      • AST or ALT 3 - 5x ULN or bilirubin 1.5 – 3x ULN: Withhold treatment; may resume therapy upon return to grade 0 or 1 toxicity.
      • AST or ALT >5x ULN or total bilirubin >3x ULN (without liver metastases): Permanently discontinue pembrolizumab.
      • If baseline grade 2 ALT or AST abnormalities with liver metastases, permanently discontinue pembrolizumab if AST or ALT increases by ≥50% from baseline and persists for at least 1 week.

Carboplatin

Renal Impairment: AUC dosing

Hemodialysis: hemodialysis should occur between 12 to 24 hours after carboplatin dose

Hepatic Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling

Nanoparticle albumin bound paclitaxel

Renal Impairment

  • CrCl 30-90 mL/min: No dosage adjustment necessary.
  • CrCl <30 mL/min and ESRD: Insufficient clinical data to date. No dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

Hepatic Impairment

  • Mild impairment (AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 1 -1.25 x ULN): No dosage adjustment necessary.
  • Moderate impairment (AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 1.5 - 3 x ULN): Reduce dose to 80 mg/m2; may increase up to 100 mg/m2 in subsequent cycles if the reduced dose is tolerated for 2 cycles.
  • Severe impairment: AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 3-5 x ULN: Reduce dose to 80 mg/m2; may increase up to 100 mg/m2 in subsequent cycles if the reduced dose is tolerated for 2 cycles.
  • Severe impairment: AST >10 x ULN or bilirubin >5 x ULN: Use not recommended.

regimen.schedule:
Paclitaxel 135mg/m2 IV over 24 hours on day 1
Cisplatin 100mg/m2 IP on day 2
Paclitaxel 60mg/m2 IP on day 8

Repeat cycle every 21 days up to 6 cycles.
regimen.dosageModifications:
Hepatic Impairment

  • Cisplatin:
    No dose reduction
  • Paclitaxel:
    For 3-hour infusion:
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.25 upper normal limit, no dose reduction (175mg/m2)
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.26-2 upper normal limit, reduce to 135 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 2.01-5 upper normal limit, reduce to 90 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 5 upper normal limit, do not use
    For 24-hour infusion:
    If transaminase < 2 upper normal limit or bilirubin < 1.5 mg/mL, no dose reduction (135 mg/m2)
    If transaminase 2-10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.5 mg/dL, reduce to 100 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.6-7.5 mg/dL, reduce to 50 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 7.5 mg/dL, do not use

Renal Impairment

  • Cisplatin:
    If CrCl 30-60 mL/min, reduce dose by 50%
    If CrCl < 30 mL/min, do not use
  • Paclitaxel:
    No dose reduction

references.referenceValue: Armstrong DK, Bundy B, et al. Intraperitoneal cisplatin and paclitaxel in ovarian cancer. N Engl J Med. 2006;354(1):34-43.

regimen.dosageModifications:
Cisplatin

Renal Impairment:

  • CrCl 10 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose.
  • CrCl <10 mL/minute: Administer 50% of dose.
  • Hemodialysis: Administer 50% of dose posthemodialysis.
  • Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis: Administer 50% of dose.
  • Continuous renal replacement therapy: Administer 75% of dose.

Hepatic Impairment: No Dosage Adjustments

Etoposide:

Hepatic Impairment

  • No dose adjustments in manufacturers labeling
  • Per Hendrayana, Wilmer, Kurth et al, 2017:
    • T.Bil 1.5–3 mg/dL or AST 60–180: 50% of of full dose
    • T.Bil ≥ 3 mg/dL or AST > 180: omit

Renal Impairment

  • CrCl >50 mL/minute: No adjustment required.
  • CrCl 15 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose
  • CrCl <15 mL minute: No data available; consider further dose reductions

regimen.dosageModifications:
Gemcitabine

Renal Impairment:

  • Discontinue permanently for Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome
  • Hemodialysis should begin 6 to 12 hours after gemcitabine infusion

Hepatic Impairment: No dosage modifications provided in manufacturer's labeling

Docetaxel

Renal Impairment: No dosage adjustments per manufacturer's labeling. Renal excretion is minimal.

Hepatic Impairment: (Normal Baseline LFTs: Transaminases ≤1.5 x ULN or alkaline phosphatase ≤2.5 x ULN or isolated elevations of transaminases or alkaline phosphatase < 5 x ULN)

  • Do not use docetaxel if: Bilirubin > ULN or transaminases >1.5 x ULN with alkaline phosphatase >2.5 x ULN.
  • Isolated transaminase elevations >1.5 times ULN: Consider docetaxel dose modification. Consider dose reduction of 20-40% reduction for grade 2 or 3 toxicity. (Minami 2009)

Cisplatin

  • CrCl 10 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose.

  • Transaminases <10 x ULN and bilirubin 2.01 to 5 x ULN: 90 mg/m2

regimen.dosageModifications:
Gemcitabine

Renal Impairment:

  • Discontinue permanently for Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome
  • Hemodialysis should begin 6 to 12 hours after gemcitabine infusion

Hepatic Impairment: No dosage modifications provided in manufacturer's labeling

 

Vinorelbine

Renal Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

  • Hemodialysis: Initially reduce dose to 20 mg/m2 once a week; administer either post-dialysis (on dialysis days) or on nondialysis days (Janus 2010)

Hepatic Impairment: Vinorelbine is metabolized substantially by the liver. There is limited data available on use in patients with baseline severe liver dysfunction. Caution is recommended with administration of vinorelbine in patients with baseline hepatic injury or impairment.

  • Total bilirubin >2 - no dose modification
  • Total bilirubin 2.1-3 - administer 50% of dose
  • Total bilirubin >3.0 - administer 25% of dose

Carboplatin

Nanoparticle albumin bound paclitaxel

Renal Impairment

  • CrCl 30-90 mL/min: No dosage adjustment necessary.
  • CrCl <30 mL/min and ESRD: Insufficient clinical data to date. No dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

Hepatic Impairment

  • Mild impairment (AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 1 -1.25 x ULN): No dosage adjustment necessary.
  • Moderate impairment (AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 1.5 - 3 x ULN): Reduce dose to 80 mg/m2; may increase up to 100 mg/m2 in subsequent cycles if the reduced dose is tolerated for 2 cycles.
  • Severe impairment: AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 3-5 x ULN: Reduce dose to 80 mg/m2; may increase up to 100 mg/m2 in subsequent cycles if the reduced dose is tolerated for 2 cycles.
  • Severe impairment: AST >10 x ULN or bilirubin >5 x ULN: Use not recommended.

regimen.dosageModifications:
Cisplatin

Renal Impairment:

  • CrCl 10 to 50 mL/minute: Administer 75% of dose.
  • CrCl <10 mL/minute: Administer 50% of dose.
  • Hemodialysis: Administer 50% of dose posthemodialysis.
  • Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis: Administer 50% of dose.
  • Continuous renal replacement therapy: Administer 75% of dose.

Hepatic Impairment: No Dosage Adjustments 

Pemetrexed

Renal Impairment: 

  • CrCl ≥45 mL/minute: No dosage adjustment necessary. If Cr 45- 79 mL/minute with concomitant use of ibuprofen, avoid ibuprofen 2 days prior to treatment, day of treatment, and 2 days following.

  • CrCl <45 mL/minute: Use is not recommended by the manufacturer (has not been studied sufficiently)

Hepatic Impairment: No dosage instructions are provided in manufacturer's labeling

regimen.dosageModifications:
Gemcitabine

Renal Impairment: 

  • Discontinue permanently for Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome
  • Hemodialysis should begin 6 to 12 hours after gemcitabine infusion

Hepatic Impairment: No dosage modifications provided in manufacturer's labeling

 

Vinorelbine

Renal Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

  • Hemodialysis: Initially reduce dose to 20 mg/m2 once a week; administer either post-dialysis (on dialysis days) or on nondialysis days (Janus 2010)

Hepatic Impairment: Vinorelbine is metabolized substantially by the liver. There is limited data available on use in patients with baseline severe liver dysfunction. Caution is recommended with administration of vinorelbine in patients with baseline hepatic injury or impairment.

  • Total bilirubin >2 - no dose modification
  • Total bilirubin 2.1-3  - administer 50% of dose
  • Total bilirubin >3.0 - administer 25% of dose

regimen.schedule:
Carboplatin AUC 6 IV once on day 1
Paclitaxel 200 mg/m2 IV once on day 1
Pembrolizumab 200 mg IV once on day 1, given first

21-day cycle for 4 cycles

Followed by pembrolizumab maintenence
regimen.dosageModifications:
Pembrolizumab

Renal Impairment:

Prior to treatment initiation: No dosage adjustment necessary.

During treatment:

  • Grade 2: Withhold pembrolizumab; administer corticosteroids (prednisone 1-2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent] followed by a taper); may resume upon recovery to grade 0 or 1 toxicity.
  • Grade 3 or 4: Permanently discontinue pembrolizumab; administer corticosteroids (prednisone 1-2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent] followed by a taper).

Hepatic Impairment:

Prior to treatment initiation:

  • No dosage adjustment necessary for mild impairment (Bilirubin ≤ ULN and AST > ULN OR bilirubin >1 - 1.5 × ULN and any AST).
  • No dosage adjustments provided in manufacturer’s labeling for moderate to severe impairment.

During treatment:

  • Patients without hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) or Renal Cell Carcinoma(RCC) also receiving axitinib:
    • Grade 2 hepatitis: Administer corticosteroids (prednisone 0.5 - 1 mg/kg/day [or equivalent]).
    • Grade 3 or higher hepatitis: prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent], followed by a taper). Withhold or discontinue therapy based on the severity of liver enzyme elevations:
      • AST or ALT 3 - 5x ULN or bilirubin 1.5 – 3x ULN: Withhold treatment; may resume therapy upon return to grade 0 or 1 toxicity.
      • AST or ALT >5x ULN or total bilirubin >3x ULN (without liver metastases): Permanently discontinue pembrolizumab.
      • If baseline grade 2 ALT or AST abnormalities with liver metastases, permanently discontinue pembrolizumab if AST or ALT increases by ≥50% from baseline and persists for at least 1 week.

Carboplatin

Renal Impairment: AUC dosing

Hemodialysis: hemodialysis should occur between 12 to 24 hours after carboplatin dose

Hepatic Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling

Paclitaxel

Renal Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling.

Hepatic Impairment:

  • Transaminases <10 x ULN and bilirubin ≤1.25 x ULN: 175 mg/m2
  • Transaminases <10 x ULN and bilirubin 1.26 to 2 x ULN: 135 mg/m2
  • Transaminases <10 x ULN and bilirubin 2.01 to 5 x ULN: 90 mg/m2
  • Transaminases ≥10 x ULN or bilirubin >5 x ULN: Use is not recommended

Nanoparticle albumin bound paclitaxel

Renal Impairment

  • CrCl 30-90 mL/min: No dosage adjustment necessary.
  • CrCl <30 mL/min and ESRD: Insufficient clinical data to date. No dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

Hepatic Impairment

  • Mild impairment (AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 1 -1.25 x ULN): No dosage adjustment necessary.
  • Moderate impairment (AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 1.5 - 3 x ULN): Reduce dose to 80 mg/m2; may increase up to 100 mg/m2 in subsequent cycles if the reduced dose is tolerated for 2 cycles.
  • Severe impairment: AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 3-5 x ULN: Reduce dose to 80 mg/m2; may increase up to 100 mg/m2 in subsequent cycles if the reduced dose is tolerated for 2 cycles.
  • Severe impairment: AST >10 x ULN or bilirubin >5 x ULN: Use not recommended.

Ramucirumab: 8 mg/kg IV on day 1

Repeat cycle every 14 days.

regimen.dosageModifications:
Ipilimumab

Renal Impairment

Prior to treatment: No dosage adjustment necessary.

Renal toxicity (immune mediated nephritis) during treatment:

  • Grade 2 or 3 creatinine elevation: Withhold treatment; administer corticosteroids (prednisone 0.5 - 1 mg/kg/day [or equivalent]) followed by a corticosteroid taper.
    • If toxicity worsens or does not improve, increase corticosteroid dose to prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day (or equivalent).
  • Grade 4 creatinine elevation: Permanently discontinue; administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent]) followed by a corticosteroid taper.

Hepatic Impairment

Prior to treatment:

  • Mild impairment (bilirubin 1 - 1.5 x ULN or AST >ULN): No dosage adjustment necessary.
  • Moderate or severe impairment (total bilirubin >1.5 x ULN and any AST): insufficient data, there are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

Hepatic impairment during treatment:

  • Grade 2: Temporarily withhold treatment.
  • Grade 3 or 4: Permanently discontinue treatment. Administer systemic corticosteroids (prednisone 1 - 2 mg/kg/day [or equivalent]) followed by 1 month corticosteroid taper when LFTs show sustained improvement or return to baseline.  

Nivolumab

Renal Impairment: 

  • Creatitine 1.5-6 x ULN- withhold dose
  • Creatinine > 6 x ULN- permanently discontinue 

Hepatic Impairment: 

  • Transaminases 3 - 5 x ULN or bilirubin 1.5-3 x ULN- withhold dose
  • Transaminases > 5 x ULN or bilirubin > 3 x ULN - permnently discontinue

regimen.schedule:
Pembrolizumab: 200 mg IV on day 1

Repeat cycle every 3 weeks.

TAS-102: 35 mg/m2 PO twice daily on days 1-5 and 8-12

Repeat cycle every 28 days.

Imatinib: 400 mg/m2 PO

Continue treatment for a total of 3 years.

Imatinib: 400 mg/day PO

Continue treatment until disease progression. May increase dose to 600 mg/day if no response is seen. In patients with KIT exon 9 (or exon 11) mutation, use dose of 800 mg/day (400 mg twice daily).

Carboplatin AUC 6 IV once on day 1
Docetaxel 75mg/m2 IV once on day 1

21-day cycle for up to 6 cycles
regimen.dosageModifications:
Carboplatin

Renal Impairment: AUC dosing

Hemodialysis: hemodialysis should occur between 12 to 24 hours after carboplatin dose

Hepatic Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling

Docetaxel

Renal Impairment: No dosage adjustments per manufacturer's labeling. Renal excretion is minimal.

Hepatic Impairment: (Normal Baseline LFTs: Transaminases ≤1.5 x ULN or alkaline phosphatase ≤2.5 x ULN or isolated elevations of transaminases or alkaline phosphatase < 5 x ULN)

  • Do not use docetaxel if: Bilirubin > ULN or transaminases >1.5 x ULN with alkaline phosphatase >2.5 x ULN.
  • Isolated transaminase elevations >1.5 times ULN: Consider docetaxel dose modification. Consider dose reduction of 20-40% reduction for grade 2 or 3 toxicity (Minami 2009)

    For 3-hour infusion:
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin < 1.25 upper normal limit, no dose reduction (175mg/m2)
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.26-2 upper normal limit, reduce to 135 mg/m2
    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 2.01-5 upper normal limit, reduce to 90 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 5 upper normal limit, do not use
    For 24-hour infusion:

    If transaminase < 10 upper normal limit and bilirubin 1.6-7.5 mg/dL, reduce to 50 mg/m2
    If transaminase > 10 upper normal limit or bilirubin > 7.5 mg/dL, do not use

Renal Impairment

    No dose reduction

regimen.dosageModifications:
Carboplatin

Renal Impairment: AUC dosing

Hemodialysis: hemodialysis should occur between 12 to 24 hours after carboplatin dose

Hepatic Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling

Paclitaxel

Renal Impairment: There are no dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer’s labeling.

Hepatic Impairment:

  • Transaminases <10 x ULN and bilirubin ≤1.25 x ULN: 175 mg/m2
  • Transaminases <10 x ULN and bilirubin 1.26 to 2 x ULN: 135 mg/m2
  • Transaminases <10 x ULN and bilirubin 2.01 to 5 x ULN: 90 mg/m2
  • Transaminases ≥10 x ULN or bilirubin >5 x ULN: Use is not recommended

Nanoparticle albumin bound paclitaxel

Renal Impairment

  • CrCl 30-90 mL/min: No dosage adjustment necessary.
  • CrCl <30 mL/min and ESRD: Insufficient clinical data to date. No dosage adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling.

Hepatic Impairment

  • Mild impairment (AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 1 -1.25 x ULN): No dosage adjustment necessary.
  • Moderate impairment (AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 1.5 - 3 x ULN): Reduce dose to 80 mg/m2; may increase up to 100 mg/m2 in subsequent cycles if the reduced dose is tolerated for 2 cycles.
  • Severe impairment: AST ≤10 x ULN and bilirubin 3-5 x ULN: Reduce dose to 80 mg/m2; may increase up to 100 mg/m2 in subsequent cycles if the reduced dose is tolerated for 2 cycles.
  • Severe impairment: AST >10 x ULN or bilirubin >5 x ULN: Use not recommended.

Repeat cycle every 2 weeks.

Paclitaxel: 80 mg/m2 IV on days 1, 8, and 15

Ramucirumab: 8 mg/kg IV on days 1 and 15

Repeat cycle every 28 days.

5-Fluorouracil: 500 mg/m2 IV on days 1-5

Repeat cycle every 28 days.

5-Fluorouracil: 370 mg/m2 IV on days 1-5

Leucovorin: 200 mg/m2 IV on days 1-5

Repeat cycle every 21 days.

Docetaxel: 100 mg/m2 IV on day 1

Repeat cycle every 21 days.

OR

Docetaxel: 36 mg/m2 IV weekly for 6 weeks.

Repeat cycle every 8 weeks.

Floxuridine (FUDR): 0.3 mg/kg/day HAI on days 1-14

Dexamethasone: 20 mg HAI on days 1-14

Heparin: 50,000 U HAI on days 1-14

Repeat cycle every 14 days.

Oxaliplatin: 85 mg/m2 IV on day 1

5-Fluorouracil: 400 mg/m2 IV bolus, followed by 600 mg/m2 IV continuous infusion for 22 hours on days 1 and 2

Leucovorin: 200 mg/m2 IV on days 1 and 2 as a 2-hour infusion before 5-fluorouracil

Repeat cycle every 2 weeks.

Sorafenib: 400 mg PO twice daily

Continue until disease progression. Dose may be reduced to 400 mg once daily or 400 mg every 2 days.

Lenvatinib: 12 mg PO daily if body weight > 60 kg, or 8 mg PO daily if body weight < 60 kg

Continue until disease progression. Dose may be reduced to 4 mg daily or 4 mg every other day depending on toxicity.

Cabozantinib: 60 mg PO daily

Continue until disease progression. Dose may be reduced to 40 mg daily and 20 mg daily depending on toxicity.

Regorafenib: 160 mg PO daily for 21 days.

Repeat cycle every 28 days.

Nivolumab: 240 mg IV on day 1

Repeat cycle every 2 weeks. May also give 480 mg IV on day 1 every 4 weeks.

Regorafenib: 160 mg PO daily on days 1-21

Repeat cycle every 28 days.

OR

Regorafenib: 80 mg PO daily on days 1-7. Increase by 40 mg PO daily every week until target dosing of 160 mg is reached depending on tolerability.

Repeat cycle every 28 days.

TAS-102: 35 mg/m2 PO twice daily on days 1-5 and 8-12

Repeat cycle every 28 days.

Pembrolizumab: 200 mg IV on day 1

Repeat cycle every 3 weeks.

Nivolumab: 3 mg/kg IV on day 1

Repeat cycle every 2 weeks. May also administer using a fixed dose of 240 mg IV on day 1 every 2 weeks or 480 mg IV on day 1 every 4 weeks.

5-Fluorouracil: 1,000 mg/m2/day IV continuous infusion on days 1-5

Repeat infusional 5-FU on weeks 1 and 5.

Radiation Therapy: 180 cGy/day for 5 days per week (total dose, 5,040 cGy)

Followed by surgical resection and then adjuvant chemotherapy with 5-FU at 500 mg/m2 IV for 5 days every 28 days for a total of 4 cycles.

Gemcitabine: 1,000 mg/m2 IV weekly for 7 weeks, then 1-week rest; subsequent cycles 1,000 mg/m2 IV weekly for 3 weeks with 1-week rest

Repeat 3-week cycle every 28 days.

OR

Gemcitabine: 1,000 mg/m2 IV over 100 min at 10 mg/m2/min on days 1, 8, and 15

Repeat cycle every 28 days.
